â€œObviously, I celebrated and had a good time,â€ Bonmati tells The Athletic in an exclusive interview two days before the World Cup final. â€œBut my goal wasnâ€™t to get to the final, it had always been to win it. And it hadnâ€™t been won yet.

Proof, if you needed it, of how ambitious Bonmati really is. The midfielder is a born competitor and knows how big Sunday is after a season in which she confirmed she is one of the best players in world football.
She won the Champions League with her club side, Barcelona, and was named the competitionâ€™s best player. For Spain, she sets the tempo for the most talented squad her country has ever had.

â€œI donâ€™t know if it will be my year or not but itâ€™s the year where Iâ€™ve had the most complete season,â€ she says.

This has been the season in which Bonmati has fully matured. She has won four league titles, two Champions League trophies and five Copas de la Reina with Barca, but this was the year she found her ideal position on the pitch.
With star midfielder Alexia Putellas injured, Patri Guijarro moved up to cover her position and England international Keira Walsh played as a defensive pivot. Bonmati was moved further forward, closer to the opposition box â€” and closer to goal.

She has always been a great creator, while also proving excellent at recovering balls when her team needs help defensively. But this year she has been more of a goalscorer than ever before â€” especially in the Champions League, where she scored five times (only Wolfsburgâ€™s Ewa Pajor scored more).
â€œI have the skills to create near the box, to assist, to score, to make the team play,â€ BonmatÃ­ says.
â€œIf necessary, I will also defend or play (with) the team in construction. But I think I bring out my potential playing closer to the box.â€
Behind her success for Barca and Spain, there is a self-demanding mentality that means she is rarely satisfied. It means she improves with each passing day, but also does not know how to savour the success she achieves.
â€œI am very ambitious, I have character and a very strong and winning mentality,â€ she says. â€œI think thatâ€™s important and that you have to have to come on strong in the world of football. Iâ€™m very nonconformist and self-demanding.
â€œThat self-demanding (aspect) sometimes has made me suffer too much but it has also made me get this far because I donâ€™t give anything up. Iâ€™m never happy with what I do because I always want more.
â€œThis mentality is what brings me to these positions. You can have the talent but the change of mentality is what makes you improve every day. And itâ€™s what takes the team to the top.â€
According to Bonmatiâ€™s father, Vicent Conca, she has always been like that. In primary school, she took her studies extremely seriously and always wanted to get good grades.
â€œI donâ€™t know where she got that competitiveness from,â€ her father says with a laugh.

â€œShe had to fight since she was little,â€ Conca says. â€œOne day she came in very angry when she was seven years old, saying that a classmate took the ball and changed the rules halfway through the game. She argued with him because she didnâ€™t understand and she was mad.

â€œShe always aspires to the maximum. I worry that she doesnâ€™t enjoy the process, the moment. Sometimes she is not satisfied with what she is achieving, it seems that she is always missing something more. She has had to work for it.â€
That same girl who complained about a classmate changing the rules of football halfway through a game is the same one who still comes home complaining her team have not played well, despite winning by a landslide.
As she has become more professional, Bonmati has taken more care of many aspects: physical preparation, nutrition â€” she became a flexitarian a year ago and put greater control over what she ate â€” and her rest. She is highly meticulous when it comes to anything that could make her a better athlete.
On team trips, she always brings her cushion with her. It is almost as big as she is but Bonmati knows rest is vital and has been able to sleep well in the build-up to the biggest game of her life.
â€œIâ€™m calm. Iâ€™m not having trouble sleeping at the moment,â€ Bonmati says. â€œThe night before will be something else. It will be a special day, a day of tension, of many emotions and uncertainty.
â€œThe good part is that Iâ€™ve experienced similar moments in other competitions like the Champions League and Iâ€™ve handled it well.â€
If on the pitch she has been one of Spainâ€™s best performers, she has also shown her personality off it by giving explanations when things have not gone well.
Against Japan, Spain suffered their worst defeat in 11 years. After conceding the third goal, it was Bonmati who retrieved the ball from the back of the net and tried to rally her team-mates. Afterwards, she was one of the few who spoke to the media.
â€œI like to come out when things are going good and when things are going bad,â€ she says. â€œYou have to show your face. Thereâ€™s no hiding. Itâ€™s what comes naturally to me. Itâ€™s my personality.â€

Spainâ€™s run to the final came after a turbulent build-up to the World Cup. Bonmati was one of the 15 players who sent a letter to the Spanish Football Federation (RFEF) asking not to be called up until changes were made to the national set-up. And she is one of the few who returned for this tournament.

â€œIâ€™m not going to hide that itâ€™s been a complicated year,â€ Bonmati says. â€œAt club level, itâ€™s been an incredible year. But at national team level, itâ€™s been tough. Iâ€™ve seen both sides of the same coin.

There will be a sense of full circle if they beat England in the final; the same team knocked them out of the European Championship quarter-finals as hosts last summer.
â€œEngland are a very vertical team with differential players up top,â€ Bonmati says. â€œEven if they play a neutral game or a game in which they are not feeling good, they are capable of scoring a goal at any moment.
â€œThey donâ€™t need to have the ball to create chances. They have verticality and a talent that can generate dangerous chances out of nothing.â€
Bonmati will be expected to play a leading role again, just as she did in Spainâ€™s victories against Costa Rica and Switzerland. But she has not stood out as much in her sideâ€™s other matches.
â€œTouching or not touching the ball doesnâ€™t depend 100 per cent on me,â€ she explains. â€œThere are times when I move around waiting to look for my position to see if I get the ball, and it depends a lot on the teamâ€™s sensations.

â€œIt doesnâ€™t have to do with people or who plays next to me but more on the dynamics of the team in each game. There are times when the game happens more on the left flank than on the right and those of us who play there have less prominence.
â€œIt depends on how the team is, the opponent, their marking and how they approach the game. There are many factors and I wouldnâ€™t like to focus on just one.â€
One of the players no longer by Bonmatiâ€™s side for Spain is Guijarro, her Barcelona team-mate who decided not to go to the World Cup after the protest by â€˜Las 15â€™. She has been replaced by Teresa Abelleira, the Real Madrid midfielder who has been a revelation as a defensive pivot.
â€œI have played with Patri for many years â€” she is an exceptional player, one of the best pivots in the world without a doubt,â€ Bonmati says.
â€œTere has been a great surprise, she has given a spectacular level both offensively and defensively. I had never seen her at this level. She is playing without any pressure, with confidence and is contributing a lot to the team.â€
Abelleira is not the only player who has surprised the world with her performances at the World Cup. Bonmatiâ€™s Barca team-mate Salma Paralluelo sent Spain through to the semi-finals with her goal against the Netherlands and opened the scoring against Sweden earlier this week. Bonmatiâ€™s worst game was undoubtedly Japan â€” although that 4-0 group-stage defeat now looks very different. But she has learnt the most from her defeats, such as in Champions League finals in Budapest in 2019 and Turin in 2022.

â€œWe had to face the games differently if we wanted to go far in the World Cup. Possibly thanks to that we are in the final. The matches we played afterwards were very complete. The bad games help the team and us to play better later on.â€
